Lower respiratory tract infections. Lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The etiology of LRTIs is diverse, including viral, bacterial, and fungal pathogens. Diagnosis of LRTIs is challenging due to overlapping clinical presentations and the lack of accurate diagnostic tests. Empirical antibiotic therapy remains the mainstay of treatment for bacterial LRTIs, although the rising rates of antibiotic resistance pose a major concern. Antiviral agents are recommended for viral LRTIs, while antifungal therapy is indicated for fungal infections. Prevention efforts, such as vaccination and infection control measures, play a crucial role in reducing the burden of LRTIs. This review explores the current understanding of LRTIs, diagnostic strategies, and treatment options, highlighting the need for further research to improve patient outcomes.

Experimental retinal branch vein occlusion in miniature pigs induces local tissue hypoxia and vasoproliferative microangiopathy. Retinal branch vein occlusion (RBVO) is a common retinal vascular disease that leads to vision loss. To investigate the pathogenesis of RBVO, a miniature pig model was created by inducing local tissue hypoxia and vasoproliferative microangiopathy through experimental occlusion of retinal branch veins. The occlusion resulted in significant retinal ischemia and subsequent neovascularization. Histological analysis revealed the presence of pathological changes in the retinal tissue, including retinal edema, hemorrhage, and capillary proliferation. The miniature pig model of RBVO provides a valuable tool for studying the mechanisms underlying this condition and developing potential therapies to prevent vision loss in patients with RBVO.

A seromuscular stripping method to create a nipple valve without metal stapling for continent urinary reservoir. The creation of a continent urinary reservoir typically involves the construction of a nipple valve to prevent urine leakage. Traditional methods utilize metal staples to secure the valve, but this can lead to complications such as erosion or foreign body reactions. In this study, a seromuscular stripping method was used to create a nipple valve without the need for metal stapling. A total of 20 patients underwent the procedure, with successful creation of a functional valve in all cases. Follow-up evaluations showed no evidence of valve dysfunction or complications related to metal staples. Additionally, patient satisfaction was high, with all participants reporting improved urinary continence and quality of life. The seromuscular stripping method offers a safe and effective alternative for creating a nipple valve in continent urinary reservoir, avoiding the potential adverse effects associated with metal stapling.

Standards for evaluating results of interventional therapy for peripheral vascular disease. Peripheral vascular disease (PVD) is a common condition with various interventional therapies available. However, there is a need for standardized criteria to evaluate the outcomes of these interventions. In this study, we propose a set of standards to assess the results of interventional therapy for PVD.

The standards include both clinical and angiographic parameters. Clinically, improved limb function, decreased pain, and increased walking distance are key indicators of successful treatment. Angiographically, the patency of the treated vessel and the presence of revascularization are important factors. Additionally, the absence of restenosis or reocclusion at follow-up is crucial in assessing the long-term success of the intervention.

These standards provide a comprehensive approach to evaluate the efficacy of interventional therapy for PVD. By adopting these criteria, healthcare professionals can consistently monitor and compare outcomes across different interventions and centers. This will enable better decision-making regarding the selection of appropriate therapies and improve the overall management of patients with PVD.

Hemodynamic effects of H2-receptor antagonists. H2-receptor antagonists have long been used in the treatment of peptic ulcers and gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, recent studies have shown that these medications may also have hemodynamic effects. In this study, the hemodynamic effects of H2-receptor antagonists were evaluated in 40 healthy volunteers. Subjects were randomly assigned to receive either a placebo or H2-receptor antagonist and their blood pressure and heart rate were monitored over a 24-hour period. Results showed a significant decrease in mean arterial pressure and an increase in heart rate in the group receiving the H2-receptor antagonist compared to the placebo group. These findings suggest that H2-receptor antagonists may have an impact on cardiovascular function and should be used with caution in patients with pre-existing cardiovascular conditions.

Acute water intoxication as a complication of urine drug testing in the workplace Urine drug testing is now mandatory in many industries. Water intoxication, also known as hyponatremia, is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by an excessive intake of water. This case report describes a rare complication of urine drug testing in the workplace - acute water intoxication. A 37-year-old male presented to the emergency department with altered mental status, seizures, and respiratory distress shortly after completing a urine drug test. Laboratory analysis revealed hyponatremia and a low urine osmolality, consistent with water intoxication. The patient was immediately treated with intravenous hypertonic saline and made a full recovery. This case highlights the importance of recognizing the potential risks associated with urine drug testing, particularly in individuals who may have a history of excessive water consumption or are at risk for water intoxication. Healthcare providers and employers should be aware of this potential complication and consider implementing appropriate guidelines to prevent water intoxication during urine drug testing.

Assessing the severity of dementia.  Patient and caregiver. Assessing the severity of dementia is crucial for appropriate management and care. This study aimed to identify reliable measures for evaluating dementia severity from the perspectives of both patients and caregivers. A total of 250 patient-caregiver dyads were recruited from multiple dementia clinics. The patients' cognitive and functional abilities were assessed using standardized tests, including the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) and the Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study Activities of Daily Living Scale (ADCS-ADL). Additionally, patients and caregivers independently rated the patients' dementia severity using the Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) scale. The results revealed significant correlations between the patients' cognitive and functional scores and their CDR ratings, suggesting that patients have a good understanding of their own dementia severity. Moreover, strong correlations were found between caregivers' ratings and patients' cognitive and functional scores, indicating that caregivers' perspectives are also valuable in assessing dementia severity. These findings support the use of both patient- and caregiver-rated measures in evaluating dementia severity, providing a comprehensive understanding of the disease's impact on individuals.

Evaluation of the fine needle aspiration biopsy in the preoperative selection of cold thyroid nodules. The effectiveness and safety of fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) in the preoperative selection of cold thyroid nodules were evaluated in a retrospective study. A total of 100 patients with cold thyroid nodules underwent FNAB prior to surgery. The histopathological examination of the surgically removed nodules served as the gold standard. FNAB showed a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 95% in detecting malignant nodules. The positive predictive value was 87%, while the negative predictive value was 91%. The overall accuracy of FNAB in the preoperative selection of cold thyroid nodules was 90%. Complications related to FNAB were rare, with only 2 patients experiencing minor bleeding. In conclusion, FNAB is an effective and safe tool for preoperative selection of cold thyroid nodules, providing valuable information to guide the management of these nodules and avoiding unnecessary surgery.

Suppressive effects of visceral tumor on the generation of antitumor T cells for adoptive immunotherapy. Visceral tumors often have a suppressive effect on the generation of antitumor T cells, which hinders the success of adoptive immunotherapy. In this study, we aimed to investigate this phenomenon and its underlying mechanisms. We found that visceral tumors, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract or liver, significantly impaired the generation of functional antitumor T cells in both tumor-bearing mice and cancer patients. Specifically, we observed a reduction in the proliferation and cytokine production of T cells, as well as an increase in immune checkpoint molecule expression. Moreover, the suppressive effects were mediated through soluble factors secreted by the tumor microenvironment, such as TGF- and IL-10. We further demonstrated that targeting these inhibitory factors, either through neutralizing antibodies or small molecule inhibitors, restored the generation and function of antitumor T cells. Overall, our findings highlight the importance of overcoming the suppressive effects of visceral tumors on T cell generation for the success of adoptive immunotherapy in cancer patients.

Regional differences in the intranodal distribution of tumor cells. This study aimed to investigate regional differences in the intranodal distribution of tumor cells in patients with various types of cancer. Lymph nodes from 30 patients with metastatic cancer were examined using immunohistochemistry to identify tumor cells. The distribution of positive tumor cells was assessed in three regions within the lymph node: the subcapsular region, the cortical region, and the medullary region. The results showed significant heterogeneity in the intranodal distribution of tumor cells. In 20 out of the 30 cases, the highest density of tumor cells was found in the subcapsular region, while in the remaining 10 cases, the cortical region had the highest density. The medullary region consistently had the lowest density of tumor cells. Additionally, the study found that the distribution pattern varied depending on the type of cancer. These findings suggest that the intranodal distribution of tumor cells can influence the spread and progression of metastatic cancer. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential implications for treatment strategies.

Thyroidectomy under local anesthesia. Thyroidectomy, the surgical removal of the thyroid gland, is typically performed under general anesthesia. However, there is a growing interest in conducting thyroidectomies under local anesthesia to minimize the risks associated with general anesthesia. In this study, researchers investigated the feasibility and outcomes of thyroidectomy under local anesthesia. 
The study included a total of 50 patients who underwent thyroidectomy using a combination of local anesthesia and conscious sedation. The surgical procedure was performed by an experienced surgeon, and intraoperative monitoring was conducted to ensure patient safety. 
The results of the study showed that thyroidectomy under local anesthesia was effective and well-tolerated by the patients. The procedure was associated with minimal complications and a short recovery period. Additionally, patients reported high satisfaction levels with the use of local anesthesia, as it allowed them to avoid the potential risks and side effects of general anesthesia. 
In conclusion, thyroidectomy under local anesthesia is a safe and viable option for select patients. Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and benefits of this approach.

Aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis for treatment of twin-twin transfusion syndrome.  Acute severe twin-twin transfusion syndrome occurs in about 1% of monochorionic twin gestations. Aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis is an effective treatment option for acute severe twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) in monochorionic twin gestations. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis in TTTS cases. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 monochorionic twin pregnancies with acute severe TTTS. Aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis was performed on all cases, aiming to reduce the amniotic fluid volume in the recipient twin. The overall survival rate of at least one twin was 89%, with a survival rate of both twins at 66%. The complication rate associated with the procedure was 14%. The study concludes that aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis is a valuable treatment option for acute severe TTTS. However, careful consideration of potential complications is necessary when considering this intervention. Further research is needed to optimize the outcomes and minimize complications associated with this treatment.

Dissection of the cardinal ligament in radical hysterectomy for cervical cancer with emphasis on the lateral ligament. The dissection of the cardinal ligament is an important step in radical hysterectomy for cervical cancer. This procedure aims to achieve complete removal of the cancerous tissue and reduce the risk of recurrence. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in the dissection of the lateral ligament as it may contribute to improved surgical outcomes. This abstract provides an overview of the dissection techniques of the cardinal and lateral ligaments during radical hysterectomy. The anatomy and landmarks for identification of these ligaments are described, along with variations that may be encountered. The potential benefits and risks associated with the dissection of the lateral ligament are discussed, including its impact on blood loss, nerve injury, and postoperative complications. Further research is needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and oncological safety of this technique. Overall, the dissection of the lateral ligament in radical hysterectomy for cervical cancer shows promise but requires additional evidence and expertise to be implemented effectively.

Hemodynamic effects of partial correction of chronic anemia by recombinant human erythropoietin in patients on dialysis.  Eighteen patients on chronic hemodialysis with renal anemia were treated with recombinant human erythropoietin (r-HuEPO). This study aimed to investigate the hemodynamic effects of partial correction of chronic anemia in patients on dialysis using recombinant human erythropoietin (r-HuEPO). Eighteen patients with renal anemia undergoing chronic hemodialysis were included in the study. Treatment with r-HuEPO was administered to these patients. The results showed that partial correction of chronic anemia by r-HuEPO had significant effects on hemodynamics. There was a decrease in vascular resistance and an increase in cardiac output. Additionally, mean arterial pressure and systemic vascular resistance were also reduced. These findings indicate that r-HuEPO can improve hemodynamic parameters in patients with chronic anemia receiving dialysis. Further studies are warranted to explore the long-term effects of r-HuEPO treatment on hemodynamics and cardiovascular outcomes in this population.

Peritoneal closure or non-closure at cesarean.  The value of peritoneal closure at the time of cesarean birth was evaluated prospectively. In this prospective study, the benefits of peritoneal closure during cesarean birth were assessed. A total of XX patients were included in the study. The closure of the peritoneum was performed in XX patients, while XX patients did not have their peritoneum closed. The patients were followed up for a minimum of XX months (median, XX months). Postoperative complications such as wound infection, incisional hernia, and pelvic adhesions were assessed. 

The results showed that there were no significant differences in the incidence of complications between the group with peritoneal closure and the group without closure. However, there was a trend towards a higher incidence of wound infection in the group without peritoneal closure. These findings suggest that peritoneal closure during cesarean birth may have a potential benefit in reducing the risk of postoperative wound infection. Further larger studies are needed to confirm these results.

Use of a central 10 degrees field and size V stimulus to evaluate and monitor small central islands of vision in end stage glaucoma. This study aimed to evaluate the use of a central 10 degree field and size V stimulus in assessing and monitoring small central islands of vision in end stage glaucoma. Sixty-six eyes of 66 patients with end stage glaucoma were included in the study. Central visual field testing was performed using a central 10 degree field and size V stimulus. The results were compared to traditional 30-2 visual field testing. The central 10 degree field testing showed a significant reduction in the number of missed test points compared to the traditional 30-2 testing. The size V stimulus also detected smaller central islands of vision compared to the traditional stimulus. These findings suggest that using a central 10 degree field and size V stimulus can be a valuable tool in evaluating and monitoring small central islands of vision in end stage glaucoma.

Myotonic heart disease: a clinical follow-up. This study presents a follow-up on patients diagnosed with myotonic heart disease. The study included a total of 30 patients, all of whom were followed for a period of 5 years. The main objective of the study was to assess the clinical progression and outcomes of the disease. Results showed that the majority of patients experienced a progressive deterioration of cardiac function over time, with the development of various complications such as arrhythmias and heart failure. Additionally, a subgroup analysis revealed that patients with a longer duration of disease had a worse prognosis compared to those with a shorter duration. Overall, this study highlights the importance of regular monitoring and management strategies in patients with myotonic heart disease to prevent further cardiac complications and improve patient outcomes.

Synergism of herpes simplex virus and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines in cell transformation. The synergy between herpes simplex virus (HSV) and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines (TSNAs) in cell transformation has been investigated in this study. It is well established that both HSV infection and exposure to TSNAs can independently lead to cellular transformation and the development of cancer. However, the potential interaction between these two factors has not been extensively studied. In this study, we examined the effects of HSV infection and TSNAs exposure on cell transformation in vitro. Our results demonstrate a synergistic effect, with the combination of HSV infection and TSNAs exposure leading to a significantly higher rate of cell transformation compared to either factor alone. Further investigation is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of this synergistic effect, which may have implications for understanding the etiology and prevention of tobacco-related cancers.

Home blood pressure readings in borderline hypertensive patients. Home blood pressure readings have become increasingly popular in the management of borderline hypertensive patients. Several studies have demonstrated that home blood pressure monitoring provides more accurate and reliable readings compared to clinic measurements. This allows for better assessment of blood pressure control and treatment efficacy. Furthermore, home blood pressure monitoring has been shown to improve medication adherence and patient engagement in their own care. Patients can easily measure their blood pressure in a familiar environment and at different times of the day, providing a more comprehensive evaluation of their blood pressure patterns. Additionally, home blood pressure monitoring allows for the detection of white coat hypertension and masked hypertension, which are important diagnostic considerations. Overall, home blood pressure readings play a crucial role in the management of borderline hypertension, helping to optimize treatment strategies and improve patient outcomes.

Elevated serum bromide concentrations following repeated halothane anaesthesia in a child.  A 20-month-old child received 25 brief halothane general anaesthetics over a five-week period to allow cranial irradiation treatments for a posterior fossa ependymoma. A 20-month-old child underwent 25 halothane general anesthesia sessions within a five-week timeframe for cranial irradiation treatment of a posterior fossa ependymoma. Following the repeated halothane anesthesia, the child experienced elevated serum bromide concentrations. This case report presents the occurrence of elevated bromide levels post-repeated halothane anesthesia in a pediatric patient. The child's bromide concentrations were periodically measured for five weeks after the initial anesthesia. The bromide levels significantly increased after each halothane anesthesia session and gradually declined over time. However, they remained higher than the normal range even after the halothane administration had ceased. This case highlights the potential accumulation of bromide following repeated halothane anesthesia in children and suggests the need for monitoring and appropriate management to prevent adverse effects.

Regional differences in the intranodal distribution of tumor cells. Intranodal distribution of tumor cells has been studied in various regions, and significant regional differences have been observed. The presence of tumor cells within lymph nodes is an important prognostic factor in cancer patients. A review of the literature reveals that tumor cell distribution varies depending on the primary tumor type and the specific nodal basin. For example, in breast cancer, tumor cells are predominantly found in the central and medullary sinuses of the lymph nodes, whereas in melanoma, tumor cells tend to accumulate in the paracortical regions. In colorectal cancer, tumor cells are commonly detected in the subcapsular sinuses. Furthermore, regional differences in tumor cell distribution have been observed within the same tumor type. For instance, in breast cancer patients from different geographical regions, tumor cells were found to be more frequently located in the subcapsular sinuses in one region compared to the medullary sinuses in another region. These findings demonstrate the importance of considering regional differences in intranodal tumor cell distribution when assessing the nodal status and determining optimal treatment strategies for cancer patients.

A protocol for the investigation of pregnancy loss. Pregnancy loss, or the spontaneous termination of a pregnancy before the 20th week, affects a significant number of couples worldwide. Due to its devastating emotional and psychological impact, a comprehensive investigation protocol is necessary to identify the underlying causes and provide appropriate management strategies. In this study, we present a standardized protocol for the investigation of pregnancy loss, consisting of a thorough clinical evaluation, genetic testing, and anatomical and histopathological analysis of the products of conception. This protocol aims to identify potential genetic abnormalities, anatomical abnormalities, infections, immune system disorders, hormonal imbalances, and other factors that may contribute to pregnancy loss. By implementing this protocol, healthcare providers can offer personalized counseling and management options for couples experiencing recurrent pregnancy loss, improving their chances of a successful future pregnancy. Furthermore, this protocol may contribute to the advancement of knowledge regarding the etiology of pregnancy loss and enhance the development of targeted interventions to prevent or mitigate its occurrence.

Premature alveolar bone loss in Erdheim-Chester disease.  Erdheim-Chester disease is a rare histiocytosis also known as lipoid granulomatosis. Erdheim-Chester disease (ECD) is a rare histiocytosis characterized by infiltration of lipid-laden histiocytes. Alveolar bone loss is a less recognized manifestation of ECD and its prevalence, presentation, and clinical significance remain unclear. This case study describes a 54-year-old male with ECD presenting with premature alveolar bone loss. Cone-beam computed tomography demonstrated severe periodontitis-like bone loss and dental mobility, which led to tooth loss. The patient showed no response to conventional periodontal treatment, suggesting a distinct etiology of the bone loss. The pathophysiology behind this finding is yet to be fully elucidated, but it is crucial for clinicians to recognize that ECD may cause premature alveolar bone loss and consider it in their differential diagnosis for patients with unexplained severe periodontitis-like bone loss. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms and optimal management of this complication.

A recurrent pelvic desmoid tumor successfully treated with tamoxifen. Pelvic desmoid tumors are rare and can be challenging to treat due to their aggressive nature and high risk of recurrence. We present a case of a 38-year-old female with a recurrent pelvic desmoid tumor that was successfully managed with tamoxifen, an antiestrogen medication commonly used in breast cancer treatment. The patient initially underwent surgical resection, but the tumor recurred within six months. Due to the tumor's location and the desire to preserve pelvic organ function, systemic therapy with tamoxifen was initiated. Follow-up imaging showed a significant reduction in tumor size after six months of treatment. This case highlights the potential role of tamoxifen in the management of pelvic desmoid tumors and suggests further investigation into its efficacy in larger cohorts.

Push-enteroscopy for diagnosis of patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin. Gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin can present a challenge in diagnosis and management. Push-enteroscopy is a minimally invasive endoscopic procedure that allows visualization of the small bowel, which is often implicated in cases of obscure gastrointestinal bleeding. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic yield and safety of push-enteroscopy in patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin. A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent push-enteroscopy for this indication was conducted. The diagnostic yield of push-enteroscopy was assessed, along with the rate of complications associated with the procedure. The results showed that push-enteroscopy had a relatively high diagnostic yield, with the identification of the bleeding source in the small bowel in a significant proportion of patients. The procedure was also found to be safe, with a low rate of complications. Therefore, push-enteroscopy can be considered as a valuable diagnostic tool in patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin, aiding in the identification of the bleeding source and guiding appropriate management interventions.

Possible role of leukotrienes in gastritis associated with Campylobacter pylori.  This study was done to evaluate the role of leukotrienes (LTs) in gastritis associated with Campylobacter pylori. This study aimed to determine the role of leukotrienes (LTs) in gastritis associated with Campylobacter pylori infection. Gastric biopsy samples were obtained from 40 patients with gastritis, including 20 with C. pylori infection and 20 without. Levels of LTs and histological changes were assessed. Results showed significantly higher LT levels in patients with C. pylori-associated gastritis compared to those without infection. Furthermore, histological evaluation revealed more severe inflammation in the C. pylori group. These findings suggest that LTs may play a role in the pathogenesis of gastritis associated with C. pylori infection and could be potential therapeutic targets in the management of this condition.

Cochlear implant flap complications. Cochlear implant surgery is commonly performed to improve hearing in patients with severe or profound sensorineural hearing loss. However, like any surgical procedure, it is not without complications. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the incidence and types of flap-related complications in cochlear implant surgery. A total of 312 patients undergoing cochlear implant surgery between 2010 and 2018 were included in the study. Flap-related complications occurred in 10.3% of cases, with the most common complication being flap necrosis (6.1%). Other complications included flap dehiscence (2.6%) and infection (1.6%). The study highlights the importance of careful monitoring and management of flap-related complications in cochlear implant surgery to ensure optimal outcomes for patients.

Indications for use of ketoconazole in management of metastatic prostate cancer. Ketoconazole has been used as an alternative treatment option in the management of metastatic prostate cancer. This abstract presents a review of the literature to determine the indications for the use of ketoconazole in this patient population. Studies have shown that ketoconazole inhibits the enzymatic activity of cytochrome P450 17-hydroxylase, blocking the production of androgens which are essential for the growth and proliferation of prostate cancer cells. Ketoconazole has been primarily used as a second-line therapy in cases of hormone-resistant metastatic prostate cancer, where conventional hormone therapy has failed. It has also been used as a neoadjuvant therapy prior to radical prostatectomy or radiation therapy to reduce tumor size and improve surgical outcomes. However, the efficacy of ketoconazole as a monotherapy is limited, and it is often used in combination with other agents such as corticosteroids. Further studies are required to explore optimal dosing, timing, and patient selection for ketoconazole therapy in metastatic prostate cancer.

Middle cerebral artery strokes causing homonymous hemianopia: positron emission tomography. We present a case series of three patients who presented with acute homonymous hemianopia and were diagnosed with middle cerebral artery (MCA) strokes using positron emission tomography (PET). All patients underwent initial brain imaging with computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which showed no significant abnormalities. However, subsequent PET scans revealed hypoperfusion in the affected MCA territories, confirming the diagnosis of MCA strokes. PET provided valuable information in identifying the underlying vascular pathology causing homonymous hemianopia. We suggest that PET imaging should be considered in patients with acute onset of this visual deficit when initial CT and MRI are inconclusive, as it can aid in the diagnosis and guide appropriate management.

Tuberculous psoas muscle abscess following chemoprophylaxis with isoniazid in a patient with human immunodeficiency virus infection. We present a case of tuberculous psoas muscle abscess in a patient with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection who had received chemoprophylaxis with isoniazid. The patient initially presented with right-sided lower back pain and fever. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a fluid collection in the right psoas muscle. Percutaneous drainage was performed, and acid-fast bacilli were identified on smear and culture. The patient was started on a four-drug antitubercular regimen and his symptoms improved. This case highlights the rare occurrence of tuberculous psoas muscle abscess following isoniazid prophylaxis in HIV-infected patients. Clinicians should be aware of this potential complication and consider tuberculous abscess in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with psoas muscle collections, especially in those at higher risk such as those with HIV infection.

Aggravation of human and experimental myasthenia gravis by contrast media. Contrast media (CM) are commonly used in diagnostic imaging procedures, but their potential to aggravate myasthenia gravis (MG) remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the impact of CM on MG symptoms in humans and animal models. Retrospective analysis of medical records revealed that 5 out of 103 MG patients experienced worsening of symptoms following CM administration. Additionally, in a rat model of MG, intravenous injection of CM resulted in a significant reduction in muscle strength and an increase in disease severity. These findings suggest that CM may exacerbate MG symptoms, highlighting the importance of careful consideration and monitoring when using contrast media in patients with MG.

Prospective randomized comparison of intravesical with percutaneous bacillus Calmette-Guerin versus intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin in superficial bladder cancer. This study presents a prospective randomized comparison of intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) with percutaneous BCG versus intravesical BCG alone in patients with superficial bladder cancer. The primary objective was to evaluate the efficacy of these treatment modalities in terms of disease recurrence and progression. Secondary objectives included assessing adverse events and quality of life. Results showed that both intravesical with percutaneous BCG and intravesical BCG alone were effective in reducing disease recurrence and progression. However, the combination therapy did not significantly improve outcomes compared to intravesical BCG alone. Adverse events were similar between the two groups, with no significant impact on quality of life. In conclusion, intravesical BCG remains the preferred treatment option for superficial bladder cancer.

Vasal injuries during childhood and their effect on subsequent fertility. Vasal injuries during childhood can have long-lasting effects on fertility in adulthood. This study aimed to investigate the impact of such injuries on subsequent fertility. A retrospective analysis was performed on a cohort of individuals who had experienced vasal injuries during childhood. Data on fertility outcomes, including semen analysis and success rates of assisted reproductive techniques, were collected. Results showed that vasal injuries during childhood were associated with significantly reduced fertility in adulthood. The majority of individuals with vasal injuries had abnormal semen parameters and lower success rates of assisted reproductive techniques compared to those without injuries. This study highlights the importance of early intervention and preventative measures to mitigate the potential long-term negative effects of childhood vasal injuries on fertility.

Autosomal dominant neovascular inflammatory vitreoretinopathy. Autosomal dominant neovascular inflammatory vitreoretinopathy (ADNIV) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by inflammation and abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina and vitreous fluid. We performed a comprehensive clinical and genetic analysis of ADNIV patients and identified a novel missense mutation in the Ttg-1 gene. Ttg-1 encodes a nuclear protein normally expressed in neural lineage cells and is involved in gene regulation. Immunofluorescence studies showed a nuclear pattern of Ttg-1 expression in affected cells. The identification of a mutated Ttg-1 gene in ADNIV suggests a potential role for this gene in the pathogenesis of the disease. Further studies are warranted to investigate the precise molecular mechanisms underlying the development of ADNIV and to explore potential therapeutic strategies targeting Ttg-1.

Pharmacokinetics of tiaprofenic acid after oral administration in fasting patients during and between migraine attacks.  This study examined the pharmacokinetics of 300 mg of tiaprofenic acid, a NSAID belonging to the 2-arylpropionic class, as a single oral dose, in 10 migraine patients during and out of migraine attacks.  Plasma concentration of tiaprofenic acid was determined by HPLC analysis. This study investigated the pharmacokinetics of tiaprofenic acid, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), in 10 migraine patients. The patients received a single oral dose of 300 mg of tiaprofenic acid during and between migraine attacks, after fasting. The plasma concentration of tiaprofenic acid was measured using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis. The study aimed to assess the drug's absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination patterns. The findings of this study provide valuable information on the pharmacokinetic profile of tiaprofenic acid in migraine patients and can contribute to optimizing the dosing regimen for this NSAID in the treatment of migraines.

Progressive coma after the transsphenoidal decompression of a pituitary adenoma with marked suprasellar extension: report of two cases. We report two cases of progressive coma following transsphenoidal decompression of pituitary adenomas with marked suprasellar extension. The patients presented with visual field deficits and hormonal abnormalities. Surgical resection was performed without complications, and early postoperative imaging showed adequate decompression. However, both patients developed worsening consciousness over the next few days, with imaging revealing massive hemorrhagic infarction involving the hypothalamus and thalamus. Despite aggressive medical management, both patients ultimately succumbed to their condition. The exact etiology of the observed infarction remains unclear, but it is postulated that the extensive surgical manipulation of the tumor and adjacent vascular structures may have contributed. Neurosurgeons should be cautious when operating on pituitary adenomas with suprasellar extension, particularly when encountering tumors with significant vascular involvement, as there may be a risk of catastrophic complications.

DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors. The DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors was analyzed in a series of 27 patients. Flow cytometry was used to determine the DNA content and ploidy status of the tumor cells. No aneuploidy was observed in any of the cases. All tumors were diploid, with DNA indices ranging from 0.98 to 1.07. The majority of tumors (22 out of 27) were classified as G1, while the remaining 5 tumors were classified as G2. No correlation was found between the DNA ploidy pattern and histological grade, tumor size, or lymph node involvement. These findings suggest that rectal carcinoid tumors are typically diploid and exhibit a low proliferative index, indicating a relatively indolent behavior. Further studies are needed to validate these results and assess their clinical significance.

The prevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection in the Peoples Republic of China.  Meta-analysis on data from 16 (two volunteer and 14 endoscopic) studies ahs been performed to investigate the prevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection in the stomachs of individuals within the Peoples Republic of China.  In this survey covering 2216 cases (89 volunteers and 2127 endoscopy patients), the incidence of H. A meta-analysis was conducted to determine the prevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection in the stomachs of individuals in the Peoples Republic of China. The analysis included data from 16 studies, comprising of 2 volunteer and 14 endoscopic studies. A total of 2216 cases were included in the survey, consisting of 89 volunteers and 2127 endoscopy patients. The results of the analysis revealed the incidence of H. pylori infection in China and provide valuable information for understanding the burden of this infection in the population.

Drop attacks with Meniere's syndrome. Meniere's syndrome is a chronic inner ear disorder characterized by episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the affected ear. Drop attacks, sudden loss of postural tone resulting in falls, are recognized as a rare but disabling symptom of Meniere's syndrome. This retrospective study aims to investigate the incidence and characteristics of drop attacks in patients with Meniere's syndrome. Medical records of 320 patients diagnosed with Meniere's syndrome were reviewed, and 42 patients (13.1%) experienced drop attacks during the follow-up period. Drop attacks were associated with longer disease duration, higher frequency of vertigo attacks, and poorer quality of life. Vestibular rehabilitation therapy and surgical interventions were effective in reducing the frequency and severity of drop attacks. Drop attacks are a significant manifestation of Meniere's syndrome and should be addressed in the management of these patients to improve their quality of life.

Fetal imaging in the skeletal dysplasias. Fetal imaging plays a crucial role in the diagnosis and management of skeletal dysplasias. This study reviewed the clinical and radiographic features of skeletal dysplasias detected during fetal imaging. A total of (number) cases were included in the study. The most common presenting signs were abnormal limb length, shortening of long bones, and skeletal abnormalities seen on ultrasound or prenatal MRI. The diagnosis was confirmed by genetic testing in (number) cases. Fetal imaging helped in identifying specific abnormalities associated with different types of skeletal dysplasias, guiding appropriate genetic testing and counseling for families. These findings highlight the importance of fetal imaging in the early detection and management of skeletal dysplasias, allowing for timely interventions and improved outcomes for affected infants. Further research is needed to enhance the accuracy and specificity of fetal imaging techniques in identifying skeletal dysplasias.

Code 9: a systematic approach for responding to medical emergencies occurring in and around a hospital. Code 9 is a systematic approach for managing medical emergencies occurring in and around a hospital. It involves a coordinated response by a multidisciplinary team to ensure prompt and effective care. This includes rapid assessment, accurate diagnosis, and appropriate intervention to stabilize the patient and prevent further harm. A key component of Code 9 is clear communication among team members, which is facilitated through the use of a standardized protocol and designated roles for each team member. The protocol includes specific steps to be followed, such as initiating cardiopulmonary resuscitation, administering necessary medications, and ensuring proper equipment availability. Regular training and drills are conducted to familiarize the team with the protocol and improve response times. Code 9 aims to improve patient outcomes in emergency situations by providing a structured and efficient approach to care.

Dexamethasone increases plasma levels of albendazole. Albendazole is a widely used anthelmintic drug for various parasitic infections. However, its low plasma levels limit its therapeutic efficacy. In this study, we investigated the effect of dexamethasone, a glucocorticoid, on albendazole plasma levels in healthy volunteers. A single oral dose of albendazole was administered to each participant, and blood samples were collected at predetermined intervals. Following dexamethasone administration, a significant increase in albendazole plasma levels was observed compared to the control group. The mechanism behind this interaction is not fully understood, but it is speculated that dexamethasone may induce hepatic enzymes involved in albendazole metabolism. Further research is warranted to explore the clinical implications of this drug interaction in patients requiring simultaneous use of dexamethasone and albendazole.

Clinical review 16: Parathyroid hormone-related proteins: coming of age in the 1990s. This clinical review examines the role of parathyroid hormone-related proteins (PTHrP) in various physiological processes and diseases. PTHrP was initially discovered as a mediator of hypercalcemia in malignancy, but subsequent research has revealed its involvement in a wide range of biological functions. Its role in skeletal development and regulation of bone metabolism is well established, with insights into its effects on chondrocyte differentiation and osteoclastogenesis. Additionally, PTHrP has been implicated in fetal development, lactation, and tooth eruption. Its dysregulation has been associated with diseases such as hypercalcemia of malignancy, osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, and tumor growth. Advances in molecular biology techniques have enabled the identification of PTHrP's structural domains and its downstream signaling pathways. This review highlights the expanding knowledge and potential therapeutic applications of PTHrP in various clinical settings.

Acalculus lymphoeosinophilic cholecystitis associated with interleukin-2 and lymphokine-activated killer cell therapy.  A case of unusual cholecystitis that developed on completion of interleukin-2 and lymphokine-activated killer cell therapy is described. We present a case of acalculus lymphoeosinophilic cholecystitis that occurred in a patient following interleukin-2 and lymphokine-activated killer cell therapy. A 59-year-old man with metastatic melanoma received this treatment regimen and developed abdominal pain and fever after completing therapy. Imaging studies revealed thickening of the gallbladder wall without evidence of calculi. The patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of acalculus lymphoeosinophilic cholecystitis. This rare form of cholecystitis is thought to be an immune-mediated reaction, possibly related to the immune stimulation caused by the therapy. Awareness of this potential complication is important for early recognition and appropriate management in patients receiving similar immunotherapy.

Mutagen sensitivity in patients with head and neck cancers: a biologic marker for risk of multiple primary malignancies.  Eighty-four patients with head and neck cancers were evaluated for in vitro sensitivity to mutagens and then followed longitudinally for development of multiple primary malignancies. We evaluated the mutagen sensitivity in 84 patients with head and neck cancers to determine if it could serve as a biological marker for the risk of developing multiple primary malignancies. In vitro sensitivity to mutagens was assessed in these patients. Subsequently, they were followed longitudinally for the development of multiple primary malignancies. The median follow-up period was 5 years. We found that 38 patients (45.2%) had an increased sensitivity to mutagens. During the follow-up period, 26 patients (31%) developed multiple primary malignancies. Among these patients, 19 (73.1%) had shown an increased sensitivity to mutagens. Our results suggest that mutagen sensitivity may serve as a useful biomarker for identifying patients at risk of developing multiple primary malignancies in head and neck cancers. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and explore potential preventive strategies.

Pseudotumor of the craniocervical junction during long-term hemodialysis. Pseudotumor of the craniocervical junction in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis is a rare complication that has been rarely reported in the medical literature. The exact etiology and pathogenesis of this condition remains unclear. We present a case of a 62-year-old male with end-stage renal disease who developed a pseudotumor at the craniocervical junction after 10 years of hemodialysis. The patient presented with cervical pain and neurological symptoms, including upper extremity weakness and sensory deficits. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a mass lesion compressing the cervical spinal cord. Surgical intervention was performed to decompress the spinal cord and stabilize the cervical spine. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of a pseudotumor. This case highlights the importance of considering pseudotumor as a potential complication in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis and the need for early recognition and surgical intervention to prevent neurological complications. Further research is required to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimal management strategies for this condition.

Edwards' syndrome after the replacement of cryopreserved-thawed embryos. We report a case of Edwards' syndrome in a singleton pregnancy following the replacement of cryopreserved-thawed embryos. The patient, a 32-year-old woman with a history of recurrent miscarriages, underwent in vitro fertilization with preimplantation genetic testing for aneuploidy. Two euploid embryos were cryopreserved and later thawed for transfer. Unfortunately, prenatal screening at 12 weeks' gestation revealed multiple markers suggestive of Edwards' syndrome. Amniocentesis confirmed the diagnosis via karyotyping, identifying trisomy 18 in the fetus. The patient opted for termination of the pregnancy due to the severe prognosis associated with Edwards' syndrome. This case highlights the importance of thorough screening and consideration of all potential risks associated with assisted reproductive technology. Further research is needed to evaluate the impact of cryopreservation and thawing procedures on the development of chromosomal abnormalities in embryos.

Use of Mohs micrographic surgery to establish quantitative proof of heightened tumor spread in basal cell carcinoma recurrent following radiotherapy. Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) is a precise surgical technique used to ensure complete tumor removal by examining the surgical margins. We aimed to establish quantitative proof of heightened tumor spread in basal cell carcinoma (BCC) that recurs following radiotherapy. We analyzed data from 68 patients with recurrent BCC after radiotherapy who underwent MMS. The median tumor size was 1.0 cm and 77% of patients had multiple tumors. Histopathological examination revealed a significantly higher number of positive margins (median: 1.5) in recurrent BCC compared to primary BCC initially treated with MMS. We also observed a significantly higher rate of pathologically confirmed tumor spread beyond the clinically defined lesion boundaries in recurrent BCC. Our findings provide quantitative evidence of enhanced tumor spread in recurrent BCC following radiotherapy, reinforcing the value of MMS in managing these cases.

Critical review of gangliosides and thyrotropin-releasing hormone in peripheral neuromuscular diseases. Gangliosides and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) have been implicated in the pathogenesis of peripheral neuromuscular diseases. This critical review explores the current body of literature on the role of gangliosides and TRH in these conditions. Gangliosides are glycosphingolipids present in the nervous system and have been shown to play a role in nerve regeneration and myelination. Studies have suggested that ganglioside abnormalities may contribute to the pathogenesis of diseases such as Guillain-Barr syndrome and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. TRH, a hypothalamic neuropeptide, has been found to have immunomodulatory effects and may have a potential role in the treatment of neuromuscular diseases, particularly autoimmune disorders. However, further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms of action and potential therapeutic implications of gangliosides and TRH in peripheral neuromuscular diseases.

Sensitivity for detecting fibrillation potentials: a comparison between concentric and monopolar needle electrodes.  The sensitivity of monopolar and concentric electrodes for detecting fibrillation potentials (FP) has never been formally compared. The sensitivity of monopolar and concentric needle electrodes for detecting fibrillation potentials (FP) has not been formally compared. In this study, we compared the sensitivity of these two electrode types in detecting FP in patients with neuromuscular disorders. A total of 50 patients were included in the study and underwent electromyography with both types of electrodes. The results showed that the sensitivity of concentric electrodes was significantly higher than that of monopolar electrodes in detecting FP. This finding suggests that using concentric electrodes may increase the diagnostic accuracy for neuromuscular disorders associated with FP. Further studies are needed to validate these results and determine the clinical implications.

Scrotal inflammatory disease: color Doppler US findings. Scrotal inflammatory disease can present with various clinical manifestations and can be challenging to diagnose. This study aimed to evaluate the role of color Doppler ultrasound (US) in diagnosing scrotal inflammatory disease. A total of 82 patients with scrotal pain and clinical suspicion of inflammatory disease were included in the study. Color Doppler US findings were correlated with clinical and surgical outcomes. The most common color Doppler US finding was increased vascularity within the affected testicle, seen in 70% of cases. This finding was associated with positive clinical and surgical outcomes, demonstrating a sensitivity of 90% and specificity of 83%. Additionally, color Doppler US helped differentiate inflammatory disease from other causes of scrotal pain, such as testicular torsion or epididymitis. Overall, color Doppler US is a valuable tool in the diagnosis of scrotal inflammatory disease, providing important information for clinical decision-making and potentially avoiding unnecessary surgical interventions.

Multiple cranial nerve deficits after ethylene glycol poisoning.  We report the cases of two patients who developed cranial nerve palsies after drinking ethylene glycol. Two cases are presented in which patients developed cranial nerve deficits following ethylene glycol poisoning. The first patient had involvement of cranial nerves III, V, and VI, while the second patient had deficits in cranial nerves II, III, IV, and VI. Both patients exhibited symptoms such as diplopia, visual impairment, ptosis, and ophthalmoplegia. Magnetic resonance imaging showed enhancement in various cranial nerve structures, with the first patient also presenting with cerebellar involvement. The patients received treatment with fomepizole and supportive care, resulting in gradual improvement of their symptoms. This case report highlights the importance of considering ethylene glycol toxicity in cases of multiple cranial nerve palsies and emphasizes the need for prompt diagnosis and management. Further research is warranted to better understand the pathophysiology and treatment options for this condition.

Manometric evaluation of jejunal limb after total gastrectomy and Roux-Orr anastomosis for gastric cancer. This study aimed to evaluate the manometric findings of the jejunal limb after total gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y anastomosis for gastric cancer. Five patients who underwent this procedure were included in the study. Postoperative manometric evaluation was performed at three different time points - 2 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months after surgery. Manometric parameters including basal pressure, phasic contractions, and coordinated contractions were measured and compared with preoperative values. The results showed a significant decrease in basal pressure of the jejunal limb at 2 weeks post-surgery, which gradually recovered over time. Phasic contractions were also significantly reduced at 2 weeks but gradually increased toward preoperative values at 6 months. However, coordinated contractions were not observed during the entire study period. These findings suggest that total gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y anastomosis lead to significant alterations in the motor function of the jejunal limb, which may have important implications for postoperative management of gastric cancer patients.

Death by smothering and its investigation. Smothering is a form of asphyxiation caused by the obstruction of respiratory airflow. This study examined the characteristics of deaths caused by smothering and the methods used in their investigation. Autopsy reports and forensic investigations of 72 cases of smothering deaths were reviewed. The majority of victims were infants (60.8%) and the main perpetrators were parents or caregivers (88.9%). Common findings included facial congestion and petechiae, as well as injuries indicating physical restraint. In most cases, the death scene investigation was crucial in determining the cause of death. This study emphasizes the importance of thorough investigation and forensic examination in cases of suspected smothering, particularly in cases involving infants and potential child abuse.

Infertility and eating disorders.  Sixty-six consecutive infertility clinic patients were prospectively screened with the 26-item Eating Attitudes Test and a study questionnaire. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence of eating disorders in patients seeking infertility treatment. Sixty-six consecutive patients attending an infertility clinic were prospectively screened using the 26-item Eating Attitudes Test (EAT) and a study questionnaire. The mean age of the participants was 32.5 years. The findings revealed that 18.2% of the patients screened positive for disordered eating attitudes according to the EAT scores. Sub-analyses demonstrated that 12.1% of participants had high scores suggesting significant eating disorder symptoms. Additionally, a significant association was observed between high EAT scores and body mass index (BMI), with higher BMI values associated with more severe eating disorder symptoms. These findings highlight the importance of routinely screening infertility patients for eating disorders, particularly in those with higher BMI, as early identification and intervention can improve both physical and psychological outcomes in this population.
