Intrahepatic lymphatics opacified during hepatic arteriography in a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma. We report a case of intrahepatic lymphatics opacification in a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). A 67-year-old male with a history of HCC underwent hepatic arteriography, which unexpectedly revealed opacification of the intrahepatic lymphatics. This phenomenon, known as lymphangiography, is a rare occurrence and has not been previously described in the context of HCC. The lymphatics appeared dilated and tortuous, suggesting the presence of lymphatic obstruction. Further investigation is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of lymphatic involvement in HCC. This case highlights the importance of considering lymphangiography as a diagnostic tool in patients with HCC to detect potential lymphatic abnormalities.

Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy in multiple endocrine neoplasia. Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy is a rare complication of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN). Here, we present a case of a patient with MEN who developed cardiomyopathy as a result of excessive catecholamine release. This condition is characterized by left ventricular dysfunction, arrhythmias, and heart failure symptoms. The underlying mechanism involves excessive stimulation of -adrenergic receptors by catecholamines, leading to myocardial damage and dysfunction. Early recognition and prompt treatment of catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy are crucial to prevent further deterioration of cardiac function and improve patient outcomes. Treatment mainly involves alpha and beta blockade, along with surgical removal of the underlying neoplasia, if feasible. This case highlights the importance of considering catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy in patients with MEN presenting with cardiac manifestations.

Chronic rupture of the Achilles tendon: a new technique of repair. Chronic rupture of the Achilles tendon is a debilitating condition that often requires surgical intervention. This study presents a new technique of repair for this condition. A retrospective review was conducted on patients who underwent surgery for chronic Achilles tendon rupture at a major hospital. The surgical technique involved using a tendon anchor to reattach the torn ends of the tendon. Postoperative outcomes, including functional outcomes, complications, and patient satisfaction, were assessed. A total of 35 patients were included in the study. The results showed a significant improvement in functional outcomes and high patient satisfaction following the new repair technique. The complications recorded were minimal, with no cases of re-rupture reported. This new technique of repair for chronic Achilles tendon rupture offers promising results and may be considered as a viable treatment option for this condition.

Clinical judgments in pain management. Pain management is a complex aspect of medical practice that requires careful clinical judgment. Effective pain control can significantly improve patient outcomes and quality of life. However, inadequate pain management can lead to unnecessary suffering and complications. Clinicians must consider various factors when making decisions about pain management, including the underlying cause of pain, the patient's medical history, and their personal preferences. Moreover, the use of appropriate assessment tools is crucial for accurately assessing pain severity and monitoring the effectiveness of interventions. Clinicians must also be knowledgeable about the different pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatment options available, as well as their potential risks and benefits. Additionally, it is important to address any concerns or misconceptions patients may have regarding pain management, as this can influence treatment adherence. By using comprehensive clinical judgments, clinicians can effectively manage pain and improve patient outcomes.

Incarceration of colonoscope in an inguinal hernia. We present a case of a 65-year-old male who underwent colonoscopy for rectal bleeding and was found to have an incarcerated colonoscope in an inguinal hernia. The patient had a long-standing right inguinal hernia, but no previous symptoms or complications. During the procedure, the colonoscope inadvertently entered the hernia sac and became trapped, leading to pain and obstructive symptoms. Emergency surgical intervention was performed to remove the colonoscope and repair the hernia. This case highlights the rare but potential complication of colonoscope entrapment in an inguinal hernia, emphasizing the importance of proper technique and awareness during colonoscopy in patients with inguinal hernias.

Doppler ultrasonography of malignant melanomas of the uvea.  Doppler shifts were detected using duplex and color Doppler scanning in 41 of 42 patients with malignant melanomas of the uvea. This study evaluates the use of Doppler ultrasonography in detecting malignant melanomas of the uvea. A total of 42 patients with uveal melanomas were included in the study, and duplex and color Doppler scanning techniques were utilized to detect Doppler shifts. The results showed that Doppler shifts were detected in 41 out of the 42 patients, demonstrating the effectiveness of Doppler ultrasonography in identifying uveal melanomas. This non-invasive imaging technique provides valuable information about blood flow patterns and can aid in the diagnosis and management of malignant melanomas of the uvea. Doppler ultrasonography offers a promising tool for the evaluation and monitoring of uveal melanomas, potentially leading to improved patient outcomes.

Primary intramedullary nailing of open femoral shaft fractures.  The cases of 60 patients with 63 open femoral fractures treated by primary reamed intramedullary nailing were retrospectively reviewed. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of primary reamed intramedullary nailing for open femoral shaft fractures. A total of 60 patients with 63 open femoral shaft fractures were included in the study. The patients underwent primary reamed intramedullary nailing as the treatment modality. The mean follow-up period was 22 months. The overall union rate was 95%. Ten patients (16.7%) experienced complications, including infection in 5 cases, delayed union in 4 cases, and nonunion in 1 case. All infected cases were successfully treated with antibiotic therapy and wound care, and all cases of delayed union eventually achieved bone union without the need for secondary surgery. The results suggest that primary reamed intramedullary nailing is an effective treatment option for open femoral shaft fractures, with a high union rate and low complication rate.

Clinical results of axillobifemoral bypass using externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene Seventy-six axillobifemoral grafts with externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene prostheses were performed since 1983. The clinical results of axillobifemoral bypass using externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) prostheses were evaluated in a retrospective study of 76 cases performed between 1983 and the present. The overall patency rate was 83.3%. The mean follow-up period was 39.8 months. Major complications included infection in 5.3% of cases and limb loss in 4% of cases. No aneurysm or prosthetic thrombosis was observed. The axillobifemoral bypass using externally supported PTFE prostheses is a viable option for patients with extensive aortic or iliac artery disease, offering a high patency rate and low complication rate.

Hypertension and acculturation in elderly Mexican Americans: results from 1982-84 Hispanic HANES. This study aims to examine the relationship between acculturation and hypertension in elderly Mexican Americans using data from the 1982-84 Hispanic Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (HANES). A total of 987 elderly Mexican Americans aged 65 and older were included in the analysis. Acculturation was measured using a composite index comprising language preference, duration of residence in the US, and generational status. Hypertension was defined as systolic blood pressure 140 mmHg, diastolic blood pressure 90 mmHg, or self-reported hypertension diagnosis. Multivariate logistic regression models were used to assess the association between acculturation and hypertension, adjusting for potential confounding factors. Results showed that acculturation was positively associated with hypertension in elderly Mexican Americans, with higher levels of acculturation being associated with a higher odds of hypertension. This association remained significant after adjusting for age, sex, education, income, smoking status, and body mass index. These findings suggest that acculturation may be an important determinant of hypertension in elderly Mexican Americans, highlighting the need for culturally sensitive hypertension prevention and management strategies in this population.

Role of oxygen free radicals in ischemic and reperfused myocardium. Ischemic heart disease remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The role of oxygen free radicals in the pathogenesis of myocardial ischemia and reperfusion injury has gained considerable attention. This review focuses on the contribution of oxygen free radicals to the pathophysiology of ischemic and reperfused myocardium.

During ischemia, a decrease in oxygen supply leads to a switch from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism. This results in the accumulation of metabolic byproducts, including oxygen free radicals. These free radicals cause oxidative damage to cellular components, leading to myocardial injury and dysfunction.

Reperfusion, although aimed at restoring blood flow and oxygen supply, paradoxically exacerbates oxidative stress. The sudden reintroduction of oxygen during reperfusion leads to a burst of oxygen free radicals, further increasing cellular damage. This phenomenon, known as reperfusion injury, can lead to irreversible myocardial damage and impaired cardiac function.

Various sources of oxygen free radicals in ischemic and reperfused myocardium have been identified, including mitochondrial dysfunction, NADPH oxidases, and neutrophil activation. Antioxidant defense mechanisms, such as superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase, play a crucial role in neutralizing the harmful effects of oxygen free radicals.

Understanding the role of oxygen free radicals in ischemic and reperfused myocardium is essential for developing targeted therapeutic strategies. Antioxidant therapies, including exogenous antioxidants and pharmacological agents, have shown promise in reducing myocardial injury and improving outcomes in experimental models. Further research is needed to translate these findings into clinical practice.

The human costs of cancer and the response of the National Cancer Program. This study examined the human costs of cancer and the efforts of the National Cancer Program in addressing the issue. The impact of cancer on individuals and society was evaluated, highlighting the physical, emotional, and financial burdens faced by patients and their families. The role and effectiveness of the National Cancer Program in funding research, promoting prevention and early detection, and improving access to cancer care were explored. Despite advancements in treatment and care, there are still significant challenges in reducing the burden of cancer. The study emphasizes the importance of continued efforts and investment in cancer research and programs to improve outcomes for individuals and reduce the burden on society.

Femur fracture with limb shortening causing occlusion of a polytetrafluoroethylene femoral popliteal graft. The occlusion of a femoral popliteal graft due to a femur fracture with limb shortening is a rare but significant complication. We present a case of a 65-year-old male with a previously implanted polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) femoral popliteal graft who suffered a femur fracture after a fall. The fracture resulted in limb shortening, which caused compression and subsequent occlusion of the graft. The patient presented with acute limb ischemia and required emergent surgical intervention. A bypass surgery using a saphenous vein graft was successfully performed. Awareness of this rare complication is crucial, as prompt recognition and appropriate surgical management are necessary to prevent limb loss in these patients.

Cardiac pathology in 470 consecutive forensic autopsies.  Cardiovascular disease continues to be the single most common generic cause of sudden and unexpected deaths. A retrospective analysis of 470 consecutive forensic autopsies was conducted to investigate the prevalence and types of cardiac pathology in cases of sudden and unexpected death. Cardiovascular disease was found to be the leading cause of these deaths. The majority of cases (94.7%) exhibited some form of cardiac pathology, with atherosclerosis being the most common finding (63.4%). Other prevalent pathologies included myocardial infarction (16.8%), hypertensive heart disease (12.3%), and valvular diseases (9.4%). Notably, a significant proportion of individuals (37.7%) had more than one cardiac pathology. These results highlight the importance of comprehensive cardiac evaluation in forensic autopsies and underscore the need for further research in identifying risk factors and preventive strategies for sudden cardiac death.

Natural death as viewed by the medical examiner: a review of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease.  A study of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease was conducted. This study aimed to investigate natural deaths through the examination of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals who died of natural diseases. The majority of cases (62%) were over the age of 60, with cardiovascular diseases being the leading cause of death (53%). Other common causes included respiratory diseases (20%), infections (13%), and neoplasms (10%). The study found that the majority of deaths (78%) occurred in hospitals, with only a small portion (3%) occurring at home. The findings provide insight into the patterns and causes of natural deaths, emphasizing the importance of understanding and effectively managing these diseases to improve patient outcomes and prevent further complications.

Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract: a case report.  A 58-year-old man was seen with obstructive jaundice and discomfort in the upper abdomen. We present a case report of a 58-year-old man with malignant melanoma of the biliary tract. The patient presented with obstructive jaundice and upper abdominal discomfort. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the common bile duct and multiple liver lesions. A percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram confirmed the presence of biliary tract involvement. The patient underwent a palliative stenting procedure to relieve the obstructive jaundice. Histopathological examination of the biliary tract mass showed characteristics consistent with malignant melanoma, including the presence of S-100 and HMB-45 positive cells. The patient was referred for further evaluation and treatment by an oncology specialist. Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract is a rare and aggressive malignancy with a poor prognosis.

Bladder function in the mentally retarded. Bladder dysfunction is common among individuals with mental retardation. In a study of 78 mentally retarded patients, 38 patients (48.7%) were found to have abnormal bladder function. The most common type of dysfunction observed was detrusor instability, which was present in 18 patients (47.4%). Other types of dysfunction included urinary incontinence (23.7%), neurogenic bladder (15.8%), and obstructive uropathy (13.2%). The severity of mental retardation did not appear to significantly correlate with the type or degree of bladder dysfunction. These findings highlight the importance of routine urological evaluation and management in mentally retarded individuals to prevent complications such as urinary tract infections and renal impairment. Furthermore, individualized treatment plans should be developed to address the specific underlying causes of bladder dysfunction in this population.

Immunophenotyping in the management of gastric lymphoma.  Primary gastric lymphoma is a rare tumor in which surgical resection plays a major role in improving the response rate and reducing the incidence of bleeding and perforation after chemotherapy. Immunophenotyping has become an essential tool in the management of gastric lymphoma. This rare tumor often requires surgical resection as a crucial component of treatment to enhance response rates and decrease the risk of bleeding and perforation following chemotherapy. Immunophenotyping plays a pivotal role in identifying specific subtypes of gastric lymphoma, allowing for tailored treatment strategies. Immunohistochemical analysis of biopsy specimens is used to determine the presence of specific markers, such as CD20 and CD3, which aid in distinguishing between different lymphoma subtypes. This information guides treatment decisions, including targeted therapies and the use of monoclonal antibodies. Additionally, immunophenotyping can aid in post-treatment monitoring of minimal residual disease and the detection of relapse. Overall, immunophenotyping is a valuable tool in the management and optimization of treatment outcomes in gastric lymphoma.

Dapsone is an effective therapy for the skin lesions of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus and urticarial vasculitis in a patient with C2 deficiency. Dapsone has been proven to be an effective treatment for skin lesions associated with subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE) and urticarial vasculitis (UV) in patients with C2 deficiency. A case study of a patient with C2 deficiency who presented with severe skin lesions of SCLE and UV was conducted. The patient was treated with dapsone, resulting in a marked improvement of the skin lesions. Dapsone is a sulfone antibiotic that has been used for its anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties. Its mechanism of action involves suppression of neutrophil chemotaxis and inhibition of myeloperoxidase, leading to a reduction in skin inflammation. Dapsone should be considered as a therapeutic option for patients with SCLE and UV, particularly those with C2 deficiency.

Gastric lesions secondary to long-distance running.  Gastrointestinal disorders have been reported during long-distance running. Long-distance running has been associated with the development of gastric lesions. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence and characteristics of gastric lesions in long-distance runners. Gastrointestinal disorders were reported in a number of runners, with symptoms including abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Endoscopic examination revealed multiple gastric lesions, including erosions and ulcers, predominantly in the antrum. Histological analysis indicated inflammation and mucosal damage in the affected areas. The onset of the lesions varied, but they were often associated with prolonged and strenuous running. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential preventive measures for gastric lesions in long-distance runners.

Neuroendocrine carcinoid tumours of the breast: a variant of carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation. Breast carcinoid tumors are rare and display neuroendocrine differentiation. This study aimed to characterize the clinico-pathological features of breast carcinoid tumors and assess their prognosis. Eleven cases of breast carcinoid tumors were identified and analyzed. The patients' age ranged from 38 to 82 years (mean, 60.1). No significant differences were observed in tumor size, histological grade, lymph node involvement, estrogen receptor (ER) status, and progesterone receptor (PR) status between breast carcinoid tumors and noncarcinoid breast carcinomas. However, breast carcinoid tumors showed a significantly higher rate of neuroendocrine markers (chromogranin A and synaptophysin) expression compared to noncarcinoid breast carcinomas. The patients with breast carcinoid tumors had a relatively favorable prognosis, with a disease-specific survival rate of 90.9% at a median follow-up of 76.8 months. In conclusion, breast carcinoid tumors are a variant of carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation. They have distinct histological and immunohistochemical features but show a favorable prognosis compared to noncarcinoid breast carcinomas. Further studies are needed to better understand their biology and optimal management.

The risk of large bowel cancer after partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease.  The relative risk (standardized incidence ratio [SIR] for colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy for ulcer disease was examined in a population-based cohort comprising 6459 patients operated during 1950 to 1958.  Follow-up through 1983 revealed 131 cases of colorectal cancer versus 150. This study aimed to determine the risk of colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease. A population-based cohort of 6459 patients who underwent surgery from 1950 to 1958 was followed up until 1983. The standardized incidence ratio (SIR) was used to assess the relative risk of colorectal cancer. Among the cohort, 131 cases of colorectal cancer were reported, compared to an expected incidence of 150 cases. The SIR for colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy in this population was found to be 0.87. These findings suggest that there is no significant increased risk of developing colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease. Further research with longer follow-up periods may be necessary to confirm these results.

Cardiac arrest during hip arthroplasty with a cemented long-stem component. Cardiac arrest during hip arthroplasty with a cemented long-stem component is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication. We present a case of a 65-year-old male who experienced cardiac arrest shortly after the insertion of a cemented long-stem component during a total hip arthroplasty. Despite immediate resuscitative efforts, including cardiopulmonary resuscitation and administration of medications, the patient did not respond. The arrest was attributed to cement embolism, which led to a pulmonary embolism and subsequent cardiac arrest. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and management of cement embolism during hip arthroplasty. Measures such as the use of cement restrictors and proper cementing techniques should be employed to minimize the risk of embolism. Additionally, prompt initiation of advanced cardiac life support is crucial in managing this life-threatening complication.

Early magnetic resonance imaging in acute traumatic internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Acute traumatic internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a rare ocular motility disorder resulting from damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) following head trauma. Prompt diagnosis of INO is crucial, as it can be a potential indicator for more severe neurological injuries. This study aims to evaluate the utility of early magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and management of acute traumatic INO. Ten patients presenting with acute onset of INO following head trauma were included in this retrospective study. Early MRI was performed within 48 hours of symptom onset and demonstrated various degrees of MLF injury. The findings suggest that early MRI is a valuable tool in confirming the diagnosis of acute traumatic INO and may aid in guiding appropriate management strategies.

A study of the comparative efficacy of four common analgesics in the control of postsurgical dental pain. Postoperative dental pain can be challenging to manage effectively. In this study, we evaluated the comparative efficacy of four common analgesics in controlling postsurgical dental pain. Sixty-four patients who underwent dental surgery were randomly assigned to receive one of the following analgesics: ibuprofen, acetaminophen, naproxen sodium, or codeine. Pain intensity was assessed using a visual analog scale at 1, 2, 4, and 6 hours postoperatively. Results showed that ibuprofen and acetaminophen were equally effective in relieving postoperative dental pain, with significant reductions in pain intensity compared to naproxen sodium and codeine. These findings indicate that ibuprofen and acetaminophen are suitable options for managing postsurgical dental pain.

Partial duplication of the face: case report and review. We present a case report of partial duplication of the face and review the relevant literature. A 32-year-old female presented with a facial deformity characterized by duplication of the midface and lips. The patient had a history of developmental delays and intellectual disability. Physical examination revealed duplication of the nose, mouth, and upper lip. CT imaging confirmed the presence of duplicated facial structures, including duplicated maxillary bones and nasal septum. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of partial duplication of the face in an adult patient. The etiology of this rare condition remains unclear, but it is postulated to be a result of abnormal embryonic development. This case highlights the importance of considering unusual malformations in patients with developmental delays and intellectual disabilities. Further research is warranted to better understand the etiology and management of this condition.

Tryptophan-induced eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome Eight patients who became ill while taking tryptophan had myalgia, fatigue, rash, fever, edema, alopecia, arthralgias, diminished joint motion, skin tightening, muscle cramping, and distal paresthesias. This study investigates eight patients who developed symptoms of tryptophan-induced eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS). The patients presented with a range of symptoms including myalgia, fatigue, rash, fever, edema, alopecia, arthralgias, diminished joint motion, skin tightening, muscle cramping, and distal paresthesias. The development of EMS was observed while the patients were on tryptophan supplementation. Further investigations were conducted to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential risk factors associated with EMS. The findings of this study contribute to the understanding of tryptophan-associated adverse effects and highlight the importance of monitoring patients on tryptophan supplementation for potential complications.

Amiloride blocks the onset of ACTH-induced hypertension in the sheep. We investigated the effect of amiloride, a diuretic and potassium-sparing agent, on the onset of ACTH-induced hypertension in sheep. Twelve sheep were divided into two groups: a control group receiving only ACTH, and a treatment group receiving both ACTH and amiloride. Blood pressure and electrolyte concentrations were measured at regular intervals throughout the study. The control group showed a significant increase in blood pressure following ACTH administration, while the treatment group administered with amiloride exhibited no significant changes in blood pressure. Additionally, the treatment group showed lower sodium and higher potassium concentrations compared to the control group. These findings suggest that amiloride effectively blocks the onset of ACTH-induced hypertension in sheep and may have potential therapeutic implications in the treatment of hypertension in humans. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and confirm these results.

Imaging the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters using transvaginal sonography. Transvaginal sonography has emerged as a promising technique for imaging the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and accuracy of transvaginal sonography in assessing fetal brain development during this period. A total of 50 pregnant women underwent transvaginal sonography at gestational ages ranging from 18 to 34 weeks. The transvaginal approach provided high-resolution images of the fetal brain, allowing for detailed evaluation of brain structures such as the ventricles, cerebellum, and cerebral cortex. This technique was particularly useful for visualizing subtle abnormalities and detecting fetal brain malformations that may go unnoticed on conventional transabdominal ultrasound. The results of this study demonstrate that transvaginal sonography is a valuable tool in the assessment of fetal brain development, offering improved diagnostic accuracy and potentially aiding in early detection and management of fetal brain abnormalities. Further research is needed to establish standardized protocols and optimize the use of transvaginal sonography in routine fetal neuroimaging.

Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions of the head and neck. Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions of the head and neck are rare and pose a diagnostic challenge. We present two cases of tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions involving the parotid gland and the submandibular area. Both patients presented with painless, gradually enlarging masses. Imaging studies revealed well-defined masses with heterogeneous enhancement. Histopathological examination of the excised specimens showed fibroblasts, chronic inflammatory cells, and vascular proliferation, consistent with a diagnosis of tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions. Treatment involved surgical excision with no evidence of recurrence or metastasis at follow-up. Increased awareness of this entity is important for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management, as these lesions can mimic malignancy. Further studies are needed to better understand the etiology and optimal treatment of tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions.

Isolated lung transplantation for pulmonary fibrosis. Isolated lung transplantation has emerged as a viable treatment option for patients with end-stage pulmonary fibrosis. In this study, we evaluated the outcomes of 42 patients who underwent isolated lung transplantation for pulmonary fibrosis. Preoperatively, all patients underwent comprehensive pulmonary function testing and imaging studies. The surgical procedure involved removal of the diseased lung and transplantation of a healthy lung from a suitable donor. Postoperatively, patients were closely monitored for complications and underwent regular follow-up visits. The majority of patients exhibited significant improvements in lung function and quality of life following transplantation. However, a subset of patients experienced complications such as rejection, infection, and graft dysfunction. Despite these challenges, isolated lung transplantation remains a viable option for carefully selected patients with end-stage pulmonary fibrosis. Further research is needed to optimize patient selection criteria and improve long-term outcomes.

Empiric treatment of fungal infections in the neutropenic host. Fungal infections are a major concern in neutropenic patients, as they have a weakened immune system and are at a higher risk of developing life-threatening infections. Empiric treatment, which involves initiating therapy without waiting for definitive identification of the causative organism, is crucial in these patients to prevent morbidity and mortality. This approach allows for immediate administration of antifungal agents to target a broad spectrum of potential fungal pathogens.

In the past, amphotericin B was the empiric therapy of choice; however, it is associated with significant toxicity. As newer antifungal agents have become available, the management of fungal infections in neutropenic patients has evolved. The use of azole antifungal agents, such as fluconazole, has shown efficacy and a safer side effect profile. Additionally, the use of echinocandins, like caspofungin, has gained popularity due to their broad-spectrum antifungal activity and low toxicity.

While empiric treatment has been successful in reducing mortality rates, cautious consideration of the patient's clinical presentation and risk factors is necessary. The appropriate choice of antifungal agent should be based on local epidemiological data and antifungal susceptibility patterns. Close monitoring of response to therapy and timely adjustment of treatment are critical to ensure optimal outcomes in neutropenic patients with fungal infections.

Association of Treacher Collins syndrome and translocation 6p21. 31/16p13. 11: exclusion of the locus from these candidate regions. Treacher Collins syndrome (TCS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by craniofacial abnormalities. Previous studies have suggested an association between TCS and specific chromosomal translocations. This study aimed to investigate the potential involvement of translocation 6p21.31 and 16p13.11 in TCS. Thirty patients with confirmed TCS were included in the study. Cytogenetic analysis was performed to identify potential translocations involving these regions. However, no translocation involving 6p21.31 or 16p13.11 was identified in any of the patients. This finding suggests that these specific loci are not directly involved in the pathogenesis of TCS. Further research is needed to explore other potential genetic factors contributing to TCS. Understanding the genetic basis of TCS can aid in early diagnosis, genetic counseling, and the development of targeted therapies for affected individuals.

The role of antihistamine therapy in vascular headaches. Vascular headaches are a common type of headache characterized by throbbing pain and are believed to be caused by excessive dilation of blood vessels in the head. Antihistamines are commonly used medications for allergic conditions, but their role in treating vascular headaches is unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of antihistamine therapy in the management of vascular headaches. A comprehensive literature search was conducted, and relevant studies were included in the analysis. Despite limited evidence, some studies suggested a potential benefit of antihistamines in reducing the frequency and severity of vascular headaches. However, further well-designed clinical trials are needed to establish the efficacy and safety of antihistamines in this population. In conclusion, antihistamine therapy may be considered as an adjunctive treatment option for vascular headaches, but more research is needed to determine its optimal use.

The value of push-type jejunal endoscopy in familial adenomatosis coli/Gardner's syndrome. This study evaluates the utility of push-type jejunal endoscopy in patients with familial adenomatosis coli (FAC) or Gardner's syndrome. Eight patients with either FAC or Gardner's syndrome underwent push-type jejunal endoscopy to assess the presence of polyps in the jejunum, as well as to detect the occurrence of adenocarcinoma. The results revealed the detection of multiple polyps in the jejunum of all patients, with a mean polyp count of 12.5 per patient. Furthermore, two patients were found to have adenocarcinoma in the jejunum. The use of push-type jejunal endoscopy allowed for the identification and subsequent management of the jejunum as a potential site for polyp development and adenocarcinoma in patients with FAC or Gardner's syndrome. Therefore, push-type jejunal endoscopy may be considered a valuable diagnostic and therapeutic tool in the management of these patients.

Uniparental paternal disomy in Angelman's syndrome. OBJECTIVE: To investigate the occurrence of uniparental paternal disomy (UPD) in individuals with Angelman's syndrome. DESIGN: Genetic analysis of patients with a clinical diagnosis of Angelman's syndrome. SETTING: Genetic laboratory at a university medical center. PATIENTS: Group of patients with typical clinical features of Angelman's syndrome. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Among 50 patients tested, 4 (8%; 95% CI, 2% to 18%) showed UPD, indicated by absence of the maternal allele on methylation-specific testing. All 4 patients had severe developmental delay, characteristic facial features, and absence of speech. Two of the patients also showed seizures. CONCLUSIONS: UPD appears to play a role in the pathogenesis of Angelman's syndrome. Methylation-specific testing can be used to identify individuals with UPD and inform genetic counseling and management.

Primary orchiectomy versus estrogen therapy in advanced prostatic cancer--a randomized study: results after 7 to 10 years of followup. This randomized study aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of primary orchiectomy and estrogen therapy in patients with advanced prostatic cancer. After a follow-up period of 7 to 10 years, the results were assessed. A total of 120 patients with advanced prostatic cancer were enrolled in the study and randomly assigned to either the orchiectomy group or the estrogen therapy group. The primary outcome measures included overall survival and disease-free survival rates. Secondary outcomes included adverse events and quality of life. The results showed that the overall survival rate at the end of the follow-up period was significantly higher in the orchiectomy group compared to the estrogen therapy group. Disease-free survival rates were also higher in the orchiectomy group. Adverse events were more frequent and severe in the estrogen therapy group. Quality of life was comparable between the two groups. These findings suggest that primary orchiectomy may be a more effective and safer treatment option for patients with advanced prostatic cancer compared to estrogen therapy.

CD34 antigen expression in children with Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The expression of CD34 antigen in children with Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Ph+ ALL) was investigated to determine its potential as a prognostic factor. Bone marrow samples from 52 children with Ph+ ALL were analyzed for CD34 antigen expression using flow cytometry. The correlation between CD34 expression and clinical characteristics, including age, white blood cell count, and remission status, was assessed. CD34 expression was found to be significantly associated with higher white blood cell counts and older age at diagnosis. However, no significant correlation was observed between CD34 expression and remission status. The overall survival rate was significantly lower in patients with high CD34 expression compared to those with low CD34 expression. These findings suggest that CD34 antigen expression may serve as a prognostic factor in Ph+ ALL and could potentially guide treatment decisions and improve patient outcomes. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore the underlying mechanisms.

Transient entrapment neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve in violin players. Entrapment neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) is a known condition in violin players, resulting from repetitive pronation and supination movements during playing. We report two cases of transient PIN entrapment neuropathy in violin players, who presented with pain, weakness, and decreased finger extension. Both cases were diagnosed based on clinical examination and electromyography findings. Conservative management including rest, modification of playing technique, and physical therapy was successful in alleviating symptoms and restoring normal function. PIN entrapment neuropathy should be considered in the differential diagnosis of forearm and hand pain in violin players. Early recognition and appropriate management are crucial to prevent chronic disability and allow for the resumption of playing activities. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathophysiology and identify preventive strategies for this condition.

Ondansetron: a new entity in emesis control. Ondansetron is a novel drug that has shown promising results in controlling emesis. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ondansetron in patients experiencing emesis due to various etiologies. A total of 200 patients were included in this randomized controlled trial, with half receiving ondansetron and the other half receiving a placebo. The ondansetron group demonstrated a significant reduction in the frequency and severity of emesis compared to the placebo group. Additionally, patients in the ondansetron group reported improved quality of life and reduced use of rescue antiemetic medication. Adverse effects were minimal and well-tolerated, with the most common being headache and constipation. Ondansetron shows great potential as an effective and safe agent for emesis control in various clinical settings. Further studies are needed to explore its optimal dosage and long-term effects.

Protective role of vitamin E in biological systems. This study aimed to evaluate the protective role of vitamin E in biological systems. Various research articles and clinical studies were reviewed to assess the effects of vitamin E on different health conditions. The findings suggest that vitamin E plays a crucial role in preventing oxidative damage and reducing the risk of chronic diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, cancer, and neurodegenerative disorders. Furthermore, vitamin E supplementation has shown promising results in improving immune function and reducing inflammation. However, conflicting evidence regarding its efficacy and optimal dosage warrants further investigation. Overall, this review highlights the potential of vitamin E as a valuable antioxidant and its importance in maintaining overall health and well-being.

Intravenous immunoglobulin treatment in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) is a debilitating disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) has been used as a treatment for CIDP. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of IVIg in patients with CIDP. Twenty-five patients with CIDP were included in the study and received IVIg treatment. The primary outcome measures were the change in the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score and the disability score at 6 months after treatment initiation. Secondary outcome measures included changes in muscle strength, sensory function, and nerve conduction studies. The results showed that IVIg treatment led to a significant improvement in the mRS score and disability score at 6 months. Muscle strength and sensory function also showed improvement after IVIg treatment. Adverse events were mild and transient. These findings suggest that IVIg treatment is an effective and safe option for patients with CIDP, providing significant improvements in clinical outcomes. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Interventional radiologic alternatives to cholecystectomy. Cholecystectomy is the standard treatment for gallbladder diseases, but there are alternative interventional radiologic procedures that can be considered. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of interventional radiologic alternatives to traditional cholecystectomy. A comprehensive literature review was conducted to identify relevant studies on interventional radiologic procedures for gallbladder diseases. The identified procedures included percutaneous cholecystostomy, percutaneous gallbladder drainage, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with endoscopic gallbladder drainage, and percutaneous transhepatic gallbladder drainage. The results showed that these interventional radiologic procedures were effective in managing gallbladder diseases, especially in high-risk surgical patients or those with comorbidities. These procedures were associated with minimal invasiveness, shorter hospital stays, and lower complication rates compared to cholecystectomy. However, careful patient selection is crucial, and long-term outcomes need further investigation. Interventional radiologic alternatives can be considered as safe and effective treatment options for select patients with gallbladder diseases.

Short-term memory and sentence comprehension. Short-term memory and sentence comprehension are cognitive functions essential for language processing and communication. This review aims to provide an overview of the current understanding of the neurobiological basis of short-term memory and sentence comprehension in the human brain. Research has revealed that short-term memory involves the activation of prefrontal cortex and parietal regions, while sentence comprehension involves a distributed network of brain regions, including the left inferior frontal gyrus and superior temporal gyrus. Various neurotransmitters and neurochemical systems, such as dopamine and acetylcholine, have been implicated in the modulation of these cognitive processes. Furthermore, studies have shown that deficits in short-term memory and sentence comprehension can occur in several neurological and psychiatric disorders, highlighting the clinical significance of these cognitive functions.

Primary osteosarcoma of the lung.  Report of two cases and review of the literature. Primary osteosarcoma of the lung is a rare malignancy with limited reported cases in the literature. We present two cases of primary osteosarcoma of the lung and review the available literature on this topic. Both cases involved middle-aged adults with no history of prior malignancies. The patients presented with symptoms including cough, chest pain, and dyspnea. Radiological imaging revealed lung masses consistent with osteosarcoma. Histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of osteosarcoma, characterized by malignant osteoid production. Treatment involved surgical resection of the lung masses, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Both patients achieved partial response to treatment and remained alive at the time of follow-up. The literature review revealed a total of 25 reported cases of primary osteosarcoma of the lung. The prognosis of this rare malignancy is uncertain due to the limited number of cases, but early diagnosis and aggressive multimodal treatment appear to be associated with improved outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology, pathogenesis, and optimal management of primary osteosarcoma of the lung.

Diphenylhydantoin-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus. This case report describes a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) who developed diphenylhydantoin-induced hypogammaglobulinemia. The patient had a history of HIV infection and was on antiretroviral therapy. Following the initiation of diphenylhydantoin therapy for a seizure disorder, the patient developed recurrent infections and a significant decrease in immunoglobulin levels. Subsequent investigations confirmed the presence of hypogammaglobulinemia, with undetectable levels of IgG and IgA. The diphenylhydantoin was discontinued and the patient was treated with intravenous immunoglobulin replacement therapy, resulting in improvement of immunoglobulin levels and a reduction in the frequency of infections. This case highlights the potential for diphenylhydantoin to induce hypogammaglobulinemia in HIV-infected individuals and emphasizes the importance of monitoring immunoglobulin levels in this population.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Pelvic pain is a common complaint among women, but its etiology can often be challenging to diagnose and treat. This review highlights the importance of understanding pelvic anatomy and physiology in order to effectively manage pelvic pain. Key anatomical structures and their innervation, including the pelvic floor muscles, ligaments, and visceral organs, are discussed. The role of the central and peripheral nervous systems in pain transmission is also explored. Various causes of pelvic pain, such as endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and pelvic floor dysfunction, are presented. Treatment options, including physical therapy, medications, and minimally invasive procedures, are reviewed. By gaining a comprehensive understanding of pelvic anatomy and physiology, healthcare providers can better evaluate and treat patients with pelvic pain.

Dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea: optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. Acute childhood diarrhea is a common condition that can lead to malnutrition if not managed appropriately. This study aimed to determine the optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets in the dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea. We conducted a systematic review of randomized controlled trials evaluating the effects of early versus delayed feeding and the choice of milk or mixed diet in children with acute diarrhea. The results showed that early initiation of feeding was associated with a reduced duration of diarrhea and improved nutritional outcomes. However, there was limited evidence to guide the selection of milk or mixed diet in these children. Further research is needed to establish clear recommendations on the optimal feeding practices and choice of diet in the management of acute childhood diarrhea.

Small bowel phytobezoar mimicking presentation of Crohn's disease. Phytobezoars are a rare cause of small bowel obstruction and can present with symptoms similar to Crohn's disease. This case report discusses a 42-year-old male who presented with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Initial evaluation suggested a diagnosis of Crohn's disease. However, imaging studies revealed a phytobezoar in the distal ileum, mimicking the features of Crohn's disease. The patient underwent surgical intervention, and the phytobezoar was successfully removed. This case highlights the importance of considering rare causes of small bowel obstruction, such as phytobezoars, to avoid misdiagnosis and unnecessary treatment. In patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of Crohn's disease, imaging studies should be considered to evaluate for alternative etiologies.

Child care practices with respect to acute respiratory tract infection in a poor, urban community in Nigeria. Understanding child care practices and their association with acute respiratory tract infection (ARTI) is crucial for effective prevention and management strategies. In this study, we assessed child care practices in a poor, urban community in Nigeria and their relationship with ARTI. Data was collected through structured interviews with caregivers of children under five years old. Results revealed suboptimal child care practices, including low rates of exclusive breastfeeding, inadequate hand hygiene, and overcrowded household conditions. These practices were significantly associated with increased incidence of ARTI in children. Additionally, caregivers lacked awareness of the importance of timely medical care-seeking for ARTI symptoms. Findings highlight the urgent need for targeted interventions to improve child care practices and increase caregiver knowledge regarding ARTI prevention and management. Enhancing access to healthcare services and promoting community-based health education programs could contribute to reducing the burden of ARTI in similar impoverished settings.

Pathogenesis of antigen-induced arthritis in mice deficient in neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G. The pathogenesis of antigen-induced arthritis (AIA) in mice deficient in neutrophil elastase (NE) and cathepsin G (CG) was investigated in this study. AIA was induced in NE and CG deficient mice, as well as in wild-type (WT) mice, using methylated bovine serum albumin. The progression of AIA was assessed by measuring joint swelling, histological changes, and neutrophil infiltration. The results showed that NE and CG deficient mice had reduced joint swelling and histological damage compared to WT mice. Neutrophil infiltration was also decreased in NE and CG deficient mice. Additionally, levels of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines were lower in NE and CG deficient mice compared to WT mice. These findings suggest that NE and CG play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of AIA by promoting neutrophil recruitment and inflammation.

Prospective payment system and impairment at discharge. The prospective payment system (PPS) has been implemented in various healthcare settings to control costs and improve efficiency. However, its impact on patient outcomes, specifically impairment at discharge, remains unclear. This study aimed to assess the association between PPS and impairment at discharge in a cohort of hospitalized patients. Data from a nationwide database were analyzed, including patients admitted to acute care hospitals in the United States. Impairment at discharge was determined using standardized measures. Logistic regression models were used to evaluate the association between PPS and impairment, adjusting for potential confounders. Our findings indicated that PPS was significantly associated with higher odds of impairment at discharge. These results suggest that the implementation of PPS may have unintended consequences on patient outcomes, highlighting the need for further investigation and potential modifications to the system to ensure optimal patient care and outcomes.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the submandibular gland is a rare malignant tumor with a unique histologic pattern. This study aimed to assess the correlation between the histologic features of ACC and prognosis, using flow cytometric DNA content analysis. The study included 32 cases of ACC of the submandibular gland, with clinical and histologic data collected. Flow cytometric analysis was performed using paraffin-embedded tissue sections. The results showed that ACC with a higher DNA index had a significantly worse prognosis compared to cases with a normal DNA index. Additionally, histologic features such as perineural invasion and high-grade tumors were also associated with a poorer prognosis. This study highlights the potential of flow cytometric DNA content analysis as a prognostic tool in ACC of the submandibular gland.

Compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots. Compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots refers to the compression and subsequent damage to the nerve roots in the spine, usually caused by structural abnormalities or pathology. This condition can result in various neurological symptoms, depending on the location and severity of the compression. Common symptoms include pain, weakness, numbness, and sensory disturbances in the affected dermatomes. Diagnosis is typically made through a combination of clinical evaluation, imaging studies such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and nerve conduction studies. Treatment options include conservative management with physical therapy, pain medications, and activity modification, as well as surgical intervention in more severe cases. Prognosis varies depending on the underlying cause and the effectiveness of treatment, with some patients experiencing long-term relief while others may continue to struggle with ongoing symptoms. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management strategies for this condition.

Prognostic significance of proteinuria one year after onset of diarrhea-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome. Proteinuria is a known marker of renal damage and dysfunction in various renal disorders. In diarrhea-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome (D+HUS), proteinuria has been reported to occur but its prognostic significance remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the prognostic value of proteinuria one year after the onset of D+HUS. We conducted a retrospective analysis of medical records of patients with D+HUS who had proteinuria measurements one year after the disease onset. The primary outcome measure was the development of chronic kidney disease (CKD) defined as persistent estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) <60 mL/min/1.73m2. Among the included patients, a total of 50% had persistent proteinuria. Patients with persistent proteinuria were more likely to develop CKD compared to those without proteinuria (43% vs 16%, p=0.03). Our findings suggest that proteinuria one year after the onset of D+HUS is associated with an increased risk of developing CKD and highlights the importance of long-term follow-up and monitoring of renal function in these patients.

Vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN: clinical and pathological features and management. Vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) are common, but their clinical and pathological features and optimal management remain unclear. In this study, we aimed to characterize the clinical and pathological features of vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN and explore their management strategies. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 100 patients with CIN who underwent vaginal examination and colposcopy. Vaginal epithelial abnormalities were identified in 45% of the patients, with the most common features being erythematous lesions and abnormal discharge. Histopathological examination revealed dysplasia and inflammation in the vaginal epithelium. Management included topical application of antifungal or steroid creams, with most patients experiencing symptomatic relief and improvement of vaginal epithelial abnormalities. These findings suggest that vaginal epithelial abnormalities are prevalent in patients with CIN and should be carefully assessed and managed to optimize patient outcomes. Further prospective studies are warranted to better understand the etiology and treatment efficacy of these abnormalities.

Effect of exposure of miners to aluminium powder. Exposure to aluminium powder in miners has been a concern due to its potential health effects. Studies have investigated the effect of such exposure on the respiratory system, as aluminium particles can be inhaled and deposited in the lungs. Respiratory symptoms such as cough, wheezing, and impaired lung function have been reported in miners with aluminium exposure. Furthermore, aluminium has been suggested to play a role in the development of respiratory diseases including asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). However, the exact mechanism behind these effects is still unclear and further research is needed to understand the full extent of the health risks associated with aluminium exposure in miners. This information is crucial for establishing preventive measures and promoting the respiratory health of miners working in aluminium-related occupations.
